verses.text: And He told them a parable to show that they must always pray and not lose heart.
verses.comment: Jesus emphasizes persistence in prayer, reflecting the need for constant dependence on God and perseverance in faith. The call not to lose heart points to the virtue of hope, crucial for spiritual perseverance.

verses.text: He said, "In a certain city there was a judge who did not fear God and did not respect man."
verses.comment: This judge acts unjustly, illustrating a contrast between human justice and God’s justice. The judge’s character highlights the greater goodness of God, who does listen to prayers.

verses.text: And there was a widow in that city who kept coming to him, saying, 'Give me justice against my adversary.'
verses.comment: Widows represent the vulnerable and powerless. Her persistent plea serves as an example of faithful prayer, trusting that the Lord hears the cries of the lowly (cf. Psalm 146:9).

verses.text: For a while he refused, but afterward he said to himself, 'Though I neither fear God nor respect man,'
verses.comment: This sets up the contrast between the unjust judge and God. Even someone without virtue eventually responds, underlining how much more God listens to persistent prayer.

verses.text: ‘Yet because this widow keeps bothering me, I will give her justice, so that she will not wear me out by her continual coming.’”
verses.comment: The phrase 'wear me out' literally means 'give me a black eye,' signifying persistence. Even reluctant human authorities respond to persistence; God, who is loving, responds far more.

verses.text: And the Lord said, "Hear what the unjust judge says.
verses.comment: Jesus draws attention to the parable’s lessons. God is contrasted with the judge: God acts with justice and mercy.

verses.text: And will not God give justice to His chosen, who cry to Him day and night? Will He delay long over them?
verses.comment: God’s 'chosen' points to the people He calls to Himself, the family of faith. Crying 'day and night' echoes the tradition of constant intercession and persistence in prayer (see also the practice of communal prayer through history).

verses.text: I tell you, He will give them justice speedily. Nevertheless, when the Son of Man comes, will He find faith on earth?
verses.comment: Jesus refers to Himself as the 'Son of Man,' a messianic and divine title (see Daniel 7:13), hinting at His authority and future return. The question about faith is a call for faithfulness to the end.

verses.text: He also told this parable to some who trusted in themselves that they were righteous, and treated others with contempt:
verses.comment: Self-righteousness versus true righteousness received from God is at the center here, echoing Old and New Testament warnings against pride.

verses.text: "Two men went up to the temple to pray, one a Pharisee and the other a tax collector."
verses.comment: Entering the temple, the Pharisee (seen as outwardly righteous) and the tax collector (despised as a sinner) set up a contrast about the true disposition God seeks.

verses.text: The Pharisee stood and was praying to himself, ‘God, I thank You that I am not like other people—robbers, evildoers, adulterers—or even like this tax collector.’
verses.comment: The Pharisee’s prayer reveals pride and self-congratulation rather than humility.

verses.text: ‘I fast twice a week; I give tithes of all that I get.’
verses.comment: Religious practices alone are not enough; humility and true repentance are required.

verses.text: But the tax collector, standing far off, would not even lift up his eyes to heaven, but was beating his breast, saying, ‘God, be merciful to me, a sinner!’
verses.comment: Beating the breast is a sign of repentance. This prayer influenced later liturgical traditions of contrition. The centrality of repentance in worship and prayer is highlighted.

verses.text: I tell you, this man went down to his house justified rather than the other; for everyone who exalts himself will be humbled, but the one who humbles himself will be exalted."
verses.comment: True justification is found in humility and repentance, not in self-righteousness. This anticipates the teaching that mercy is foundational to salvation and emphasizes the need for sacramental reconciliation.

verses.text: Now they were bringing even infants to Him that He might touch them. But when the disciples saw it, they rebuked them.
verses.comment: Bringing infants to Jesus shows that even those unable to understand can receive His blessing, hinting at the universality of grace from the earliest age.

verses.text: But Jesus called them to Him, saying, "Let the little children come to Me, and do not hinder them, for to such belongs the kingdom of God."
verses.comment: Jesus welcomes children, embracing the weakest and most vulnerable—underscoring the teaching that the Kingdom is a gift, not earned. This was historically interpreted as a support for God’s grace being available to all, regardless of age (cf. practice of baptizing infants by the earliest Church).

verses.text: Truly, I say to you, whoever does not receive the kingdom of God like a little child will never enter it."
verses.comment: Humility, trust, and openness mark true discipleship. The requirement to 'receive' suggests receptivity to God’s grace.

verses.text: And a certain ruler asked Him, 'Good Teacher, what must I do to inherit eternal life?'
verses.comment: The question about inheriting eternal life is central to the Gospel’s message. Note the term 'inherit,' signifying God’s gift, not a personal achievement.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, 'Why do you call Me good? No one is good except God alone.'
verses.comment: Jesus' question is not a denial of His divine goodness but a subtle invitation to recognize His divinity (cf. John 10:30).

verses.text: 'You know the commandments: "Do not commit adultery, Do not murder, Do not steal, Do not bear false witness, Honor your father and mother."'
verses.comment: Jesus lists the commandments from the Law (Torah) as foundational for godly living.

verses.text: And he said, 'All these I have kept from my youth.'
verses.comment: The ruler’s claim reflects a sincere yet incomplete understanding of God’s demands. External obedience apart from an interior transformation is insufficient.

verses.text: When Jesus heard this, He said to him, 'Still you lack one thing. Sell all that you have and distribute to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven. Then come, follow Me.'
verses.comment: Jesus invites the ruler to embrace poverty for the sake of the Kingdom and follow Him. Radical discipleship and detachment from wealth anticipate the spiritual counsels advocated by later Christian tradition.

verses.text: But when he heard these things, he became very sad, for he was extremely rich.
verses.comment: Attachment to wealth can hinder the response to God’s call. The challenge represents the cost of discipleship.

verses.text: Jesus, looking at him, said, 'How hard it is for those who have riches to enter the kingdom of God!'
verses.comment: Earthly riches present spiritual obstacles if they become idols. Detachment and generosity are essential virtues.

verses.text: Indeed, it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the kingdom of God."
verses.comment: The hyperbole underscores the danger of trusting in wealth and the necessity of God’s grace for salvation.

verses.text: Those who heard it said, 'Then who can be saved?'
verses.comment: The disciples recognize that salvation is beyond human achievement and requires divine intervention.

verses.text: But He said, 'What is impossible with men is possible with God.'
verses.comment: This statement reveals God’s sovereign power in salvation, foreshadowing the need for cooperation with divine grace.

verses.text: And Peter said, 'See, we have left our own things and followed You.'
verses.comment: Peter points to the cost of discipleship. The apostles set an example of leaving worldly attachments for the sake of Christ.

verses.text: And He said to them, 'Truly, I say to you, there is no one who has left house or wife or brothers or parents or children, for the sake of the kingdom of God,
verses.comment: Jesus promises reward for those who make sacrifices for the Kingdom. The passage affirms the value of total commitment, which the earliest Christians often lived out in community.

verses.text: who will not receive many times more in this time, and in the age to come eternal life."
verses.comment: Here, both present and eternal rewards are promised, reinforcing the hope of life beyond this world and encouraging perseverance.

verses.text: And taking the twelve, He said to them, "See, we are going up to Jerusalem, and everything that is written about the Son of Man by the prophets will be accomplished."
verses.comment: Jesus here predicts His passion, death, and resurrection, fulfilling Old Testament prophecy and claiming His identity as the suffering Messiah.

verses.text: "For He will be delivered over to the Gentiles and will be mocked and shamefully treated and spit upon."
verses.comment: This description fulfills prophetic imagery, demonstrating Jesus’s foreknowledge and willingness to suffer out of love for humanity.

verses.text: "And after flogging Him, they will kill Him, and on the third day He will rise."
verses.comment: Explicit prophecy of Jesus’ passion and resurrection, a sign of His divine authority and foreknowledge. The third day resurrection matches Old Testament themes.

verses.text: But they understood none of these things; this saying was hidden from them, and they did not grasp what was said.
verses.comment: The disciples’ lack of understanding highlights the need for divine revelation to understand the mystery of salvation.

verses.text: As He drew near to Jericho, a blind man was sitting by the roadside begging.
verses.comment: The blind man’s physical blindness represents spiritual blindness, which only Jesus can heal.

verses.text: And hearing a crowd going by, he asked what this meant.
verses.comment: The blind man’s curiosity sets up his encounter with Jesus.

verses.text: They told him, 'Jesus of Nazareth is passing by.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ reputation precedes Him, marking Him as a figure of hope and healing.

verses.text: And he cried out, 'Jesus, Son of David, have mercy on me!'
verses.comment: 'Son of David' is a messianic title, expressing faith that Jesus is the anointed King and Savior. The plea for mercy connects with the foundational prayer of repentance used in worship traditions.

verses.text: Those who were in front rebuked him, telling him to be quiet. But he cried out all the more, 'Son of David, have mercy on me!'
verses.comment: Persistence in prayer is once again highlighted, and the man's faith is intensified by opposition.

verses.text: And Jesus stopped and commanded him to be brought to Him. And when he came near, He asked him,
verses.comment: Jesus initiates an encounter, responding to faith with compassion. The structure mirrors intercessory prayers—Jesus’ attention to the needy.

verses.text: "What do you want Me to do for you?" He said, "Lord, let me recover my sight."
verses.comment: The man directly confesses both his need and Jesus’ power to heal. Addressing Jesus as 'Lord' affirms faith in His authority.

verses.text: And Jesus said to him, 'Receive your sight; your faith has made you well.'
verses.comment: Faith is both the human response and the channel for Jesus’ healing power—physical healing foreshadows spiritual restoration.

verses.text: And immediately he received his sight and followed Him, glorifying God. And all the people, when they saw it, gave praise to God.
verses.comment: The story concludes with communal worship and witness, as the healed man follows Jesus. Healing leads to discipleship and glorification of God—a recurring theme in Christian worship and life.
